People really seem to love this system as opposed to me putting them up individually, and I can understand why. It lets you compare all the rifles at once, instead of settling for one you may or may not really like. As I said, I'm a collector, so I try to make it as friendly and fun as possible. I can also answer just about any question you have about Mosins; from cleaning to shooting, I know it by heart. These rifles are pretty, tough-as-Russian-winters, and simple to clean. Easily the lowest-maintenance rifle in existence.


   Now, in addition to the Mosins, I have some very interesting pieces for sale as well. All of these are brand-new, never fired;


-Pietta Stainless Steel 1858 Army Model, .44            -        SOLD
-Pietta Blued 1858 Army Model, .44                        -        SOLD
-Pietta 'Johnny Reb' Colt Navy, .44                          -        $250

I also have these two, both have been fired, but cleaned. Still in very nice condition;

-Jukar Percussion pistol, .45                                   -        $80
-Hawken Rifle(with hair-trigger), .54                       -         SOLD



   Finally, I have what most would consider the epitome of a black powder collection. In fact I've already had offers on it, but I chose to save it for Armslist. A 2-pounder field cannon, the same one you might have found accompanying trade ships into Indian country in the early 1800's(nothing says 'let's make a deal' like some heavy artillery...), mounted on a home-made(functional, albeit ugly) stand. Some slight surface rust has accumulated since I had to store it in the garage, but nothing a half-hour and steel wool can't fix. This little cannon is small, but packs a HUGE punch. Two shots felled a pine tree on our private range in Washington(probably the coolest shooting adventure I've had yet). It fires, nominally, 1-1/2" round shot(weighing in just under 2lb), but we had plenty of fun loading it with metal BB's in a canister round(which absolutely shredded a piece of plywood, and a line of unfortunate pumpkin soldiers). The barrel was cast in 2011. It needs some TLC, that's for sure, but it is fully functional. Really the only issues as I see it are the surface rust and the rough weld-lines('rough' herein meaning 'ugly'). Doesn't actually affect the firing, but I'm a sucker for smooth symmetric barrels, so it bothers me. A cannon primer and the last of my fuse wire is also included. Unfortunately, I somewhat over-zealously shot all the rounds we had, so it does not include ammunition or powder. However, contact any ball-bearing factory and you'll be able to get them by the thousand.


-2lb field cannon, with cannon primer and fuse wire              -                 $220


  The low cost(as compared to other cannon) is because of the facts that it A) was homemade, as opposed to 'professionally' built, B) has some surface rust, C) has no ammunition/powder, D) I find the mount/weld lines to be ugly. However, it was made by a professional machine smith, just not in a professional setting. He has his own shop in his secondary garage, and has been making cannons for decades.



    Now, for those of you who might not have hard cash, I am always willing to take a look at trades. At the moment, I am looking specifically for the listed below, but feel free to show me anything. I love guns of all types. The only thing I will not consider are super-expensive, not very interesting('tacticool' AR15's being a classic example), and those newer muzzle-loading rifles, with the weird pellets and centerfire systems. I'm more of a traditionalist, in case you couldn't tell by all the Mosins. Wood and steel I love, plastic starts to lose my interest. But don't be discouraged; worst I can say is no.


-Finnish Mosin, any year, any condition, I really want one of these beauties. M39's preferred, but I'll look at any.

-Finnish Maxim(distinct from the Russian Maxim by the large water cap on the jacket for shoving in snow instead of water). It must be chambered 7.62x54R. I would prefer a cheap kit as opposed to a beautiful, Stalin-himself-fired-this-Maxim, as I enjoy project guns. Slight damage is ok, but must have all the parts, including barrel and hopefully receiver(semi-automatic, of course). The name of the game here is the cheapest functional, non-damaged Maxim. I will for a certainty be taking her out to shoot, so no brass Maxims, no perfect museum quality pieces, etc. I'm hoping to find someone who has one of the full kits from the 1990's. Finnish is preferred by I will take a look at any Maxim chambered for 7.62. This is the single gun I'm missing from my Soviet collection; if you have one, I will trade just about anything I own for it, and if I don't have what you want, I will damn well find what you want. Bonus points if it has the classic shield and carriage, as opposed to a tripod. Older years are preferred, but after a decade of searching, I'm not too picky. Huge bonus points if it is WWI/Bolshevik era Maxim. I should mention, I will not even consider 'scalper' prices on this; one gentleman wanted $8600 for just the rifle, no carriage or shield. Unequivocal, laughable no. That is 40 Mosins(or a car), to put that in perspective. I've waited a decade; I can wait another.

-Nagant revolver/Tokarev 9mm. I have essentially no pistols, having focused almost completely on rifles, so I'm looking around for some good-old-fashioned Soviet pistols. Bonus points if you happen to have extras.

-1911, .45ACP. Rock Island(Armscor) or Colt preferred.

    Well, a novel or two later and my hands are sore. Be quick to reply! Last year, my 'surplus' collection sold within 4 days; utter pandemonium. That's it for now Armslist, I look forward to a full inbox again.

I searched for about 9 months before I found this beauty in LIKE NEW condition. I dare say you could look much longer & NEVER find one in such pristine condition. This is a 3rd Generation gun made somewhere in the mid 1990's (my best guess) & was favorite among cops & the public as a larger 9mm carry gun. This one shows no signs of having been holstered or carried & has probably had less than 60 rounds fired through it. Remarkably accurate with very mild recoil. Although they say 15 rounds…As with most magazines getting the last 2 rounds seated may be a struggle. A variety of magazines are out there for the 3rd generation S&Ws. 

Mechanically, the 5943 offers all of the same features as any of the other full size, original double column 9mm’s that were part of the 3rd Generation line except for their trigger mechanism and the components related to it. The main thing however is the actual operation of the trigger. As a gun sold by the factory as being “Double Action Only” it is obviously “Double Action” for every shot but its travel is much shorter than the first shot and its overall movement is not at all like the follow up Single Action shots on those guns either. You are much less likely to have an accidental discharge with this gun. The first shot is a very deliberate action… Does that make it bad? Of course not. And if you look at some of the threads on this Board here dealing with Pistols, you will see that a lot of people actually prefer it over the “Traditional” guns. It’s just “different” and you simply need to know that going in and make up your own mind in regard to whether or not you like it or if it is “right” for you.
